marklogic.body:
"Gary Ross deliberately chose not to make a slick blockbuster, the sort of film the Capitol would make, instead going the handheld-camera route, which gives the film realism and immediacy."
Sorry to disagree with you, but judging from the number of times my wife's been driven out of the theater by shakycam-induced Nausea, "the handheld-camera route" is now the hallmark of the "slick Hollywood blockbuster". Pity, really, because she was looking forward to seeing this one.
"It's not as if the whole movie is shot like a documentary, though"
The irony is that actual documentary cameramen make every effort to keep the camera as steady as humanly possible. Skilled directors and actors used to be able to create a sense of immediacy, suspense, anguish, terror, and so on, even with the camera fixed to a tripod, crane, or Steadicam mount. But I guess it's easier to skip all that hard work and just wobble the camera around instead.
